articles.headline: When a Done Deal Unravels
articles.snippet: Hexion agreed to buy Huntsman Chemical for $10.6 billion, or $28 a share. But Hexion called it off, and the lawsuits started flying.
articles.abstract: Hexion agreed to buy Huntsman Chemical for $10.6 billion, or $28 a share. But Hexion called it off, and the lawsuits started flying.
articles.lead_paragraph: Peter Huntsman, the chief executive of Huntsman Chemical, thought he had a solid deal. When some on Wall Street showed their doubts, he bet millions they were wrong.

articles.headline: A Company Computer and Questions About E-Mail Privacy
articles.snippet: A lawsuit involves an unsettled area of the law, where changes in technology create tension between expectations of personal privacy and companies’ rights to monitor equipment.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit involves an unsettled area of the law, where changes in technology create tension between expectations of personal privacy and companies’ rights to monitor equipment.
articles.lead_paragraph: When he was fired, Scott Sidell was angry enough. Then he found out that his former employer was reading his personal Yahoo e-mail messages, after he had left the company.

articles.headline: Google Tries Tighter Aim for Web Ads
articles.snippet: Google is for the first time testing ways to use some of its data about online behavior to aim ads at Web users.
articles.abstract: Google is for the first time testing ways to use some of its data about online behavior to aim ads at Web users.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google, with its deep reservoir of data about online behavior gathered by tracking hundreds of millions of computers, is for the first time testing ways to use some of that data to aim ads at Web users.

articles.headline: Complex Ties Lead Ally Not to Condemn Mugabe
articles.snippet: South Africa’s president, Thabo Mbeki, is convinced that he can resolve the Zimbabwe crisis through patient negotiations with Robert Mugabe.
articles.abstract: South Africa’s president, Thabo Mbeki, is convinced that he can resolve the Zimbabwe crisis through patient negotiations with Robert Mugabe.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG  President Robert Mugabe’s enforcers had already begun to rampage across Zimbabwe, beating his political opponents, when television cameras captured a startling image of Mr. Mugabe holding hands with the smiling South African president, Thabo Mbeki, a professed champion of African democracy.
articles.byline: By Celia W. Dugger and Barry Bearak

articles.headline: Post-Spitzer, a New Breed of Reformer
articles.snippet: Slowly, even a bit gently, Eliot Spitzer’s successor as the attorney general of New York, Andrew M. Cuomo, is shaking up the financial industry.
articles.abstract: Slowly, even a bit gently, Eliot Spitzer’s successor as the attorney general of New York, Andrew M. Cuomo, is shaking up the financial industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: No one is dusting off those valiant titles once bestowed on Eliot Spitzer, honorifics like “The Enforcer” and “Sheriff of Wall Street.” But slowly, even a bit gently, Mr. Spitzer’s successor as the attorney general of New York, Andrew M. Cuomo, is shaking up the financial industry.

articles.headline: Take Out the Trash Precisely, Now. It’s the Law.
articles.snippet: Threatened with steep fines if they dump too much trash, local governments in Britain are imposing strict regimens to force residents to produce less and recycle more.
articles.abstract: Threatened with steep fines if they dump too much trash, local governments in Britain are imposing strict regimens to force residents to produce less and recycle more.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHITEHAVEN, England  The citizens of Whitehaven try, really they do. They separate out their cans, their paper, their cardboard and their glass, and they recycle them all. They compost. They jump up and down on their trash to cram it into their government-issued garbage cans, and they put the trash out for collection at exactly 7 a.m., twice a month.

articles.headline: Microsoft Seeks Path Beyond Gates’s Legacy
articles.snippet: As Bill Gates moves on, it will be up to successors to master the Internet’s challenges or see Microsoft’s stature erode.
articles.abstract: As Bill Gates moves on, it will be up to successors to master the Internet’s challenges or see Microsoft’s stature erode.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill Gates is retiring, sort of. He is still only 52, and he is going off to spend more time guiding the world’s richest philanthropy, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. He will still be Microsoft’s chairman and largest shareholder, but Friday is his last day as a full-time worker at the software giant, marking the unofficial end of his career as a business leader.

articles.headline: Suit Claims UBS Misled Investors
articles.snippet: The top securities regulator in Massachusetts has sued UBS, saying that the firm misled clients when it sold them auction-rate securities.
articles.abstract: The top securities regulator in Massachusetts has sued UBS, saying that the firm misled clients when it sold them auction-rate securities.
articles.lead_paragraph: The top securities regulator in Massachusetts has sued UBS on the grounds of fraud, saying that the firm misled clients when it sold them auction-rate securities and that it pushed the increasingly risky instruments on individual investors to reduce its own potential losses.

articles.headline: Gloom Descends Over Wall Street Again
articles.snippet: After rallying for a few hopeful months this spring, the stock market is sinking to its lowest level in years.
articles.abstract: After rallying for a few hopeful months this spring, the stock market is sinking to its lowest level in years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once more, gloom is descending over Wall Street.

articles.headline: Bush Rebuffs Hard-Liners to Ease North Korean Curbs
articles.snippet: The decision to take North Korea off the list of state sponsors of terrorism was a victory of the State Department over the Department of Defense.
articles.abstract: The decision to take North Korea off the list of state sponsors of terrorism was a victory of the State Department over the Department of Defense.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Two days ago, during an off-the-record session with a group of foreign policy experts, Vice President Dick Cheney got a question he did not want to answer. “Mr. Vice President,” asked one of them, “I understand that on Wednesday or Thursday, we are going to de-list North Korea from the terrorism blacklist. Could you please set the context for this decision?”
